results.content:
Overall it was an awesome course and I've learned a lot from this course.

But I've two concerns about this, first is, Resolvers are missing in the course which I think is a crucial part of the amplify and you should consider adding it in your course. The second is this course is related to AWS amplify and you have added a lot about react and less about AWS amplify mean the ratio is not fair. Again, it is an amazing course.

results.content:
If you are serious about software development you are gonna love Reed's approach to sharing his knowledge. No splash screens, no self-advertising videos nor the pretension of "I'm gonna teach you...". And I take that as his intention to respect his audience. Through absence of itelectual arrogance he makes you feel "we are in the same boat".
This is not the first time I've enrolled on his courses, and at least for the ones I had, he delivers as he guides you through his thinking process, so get ready to move fast between different componets and functions at once and pick his pace up so you don't get yourself lost. He types fast, but thinks exponentially faster. Definitively not a react/node beginners course. 
By the end, through the repetition of patterns instead-of himself, he depicts AWS Amplify leaving you ready to brainstorm its usage.
Undoubtedly a breed apart from the instructors in Udemy.
results.content_html:

results.content:
This course is great! To the point without a lot of needless explanation. 

It's not for beginners, but if you are trying to make React Apps with AWS Amplify CLI, I would assume you already know React and something about AWS. 

I would love it if the author would show us how to add Analytics with Amplify to a React App as well. But what is shown is great, and really helped me to understand what AWS Amplify can do and how to use it.
results.content_html:
This course is great! To the point without a lot of needless explanation.

It's not for beginners, but if you are trying to make React Apps with AWS Amplify CLI, I would assume you already know React and something about AWS.

I would love it if the author would show us how to add Analytics with Amplify to a React App as well. But what is shown is great, and really helped me to understand what AWS Amplify can do and how to use it.

results.content: The course is a good walk-through of amplify examples, but gets distracted a bit in purely react concerns. A major downside are the lack of test questions/quizzes and online practicals/exercises. There isn't much in the way of testing your understanding or comprehension.
results.content_html: The course is a good walk-through of amplify examples, but gets distracted a bit in purely react concerns. A major downside are the lack of test questions/quizzes and online practicals/exercises. There isn't much in the way of testing your understanding or comprehension.

results.content: A great course.  Some of the amplify instructions seemed a little outdated but was easily able to follow through with the course.
results.content_html: A great course. Some of the amplify instructions seemed a little outdated but was easily able to follow through with the course.

results.content: This is a great course if you already understand React at a basic level and are looking to learn how to integrate Amplify and AppSync into your skill set. You could probably do the course with no React knowledge, but your learning will be restricted to doing what the instructor says, with limited understanding of why. The course was published in Dec 2018, so it takes a bit of wrangling if you're using the latest version of Amplify and the npm modules, but nothing that is unsurmountable with Google to help (that is part of being a developer anyway).
results.content_html: This is a great course if you already understand React at a basic level and are looking to learn how to integrate Amplify and AppSync into your skill set. You could probably do the course with no React knowledge, but your learning will be restricted to doing what the instructor says, with limited understanding of why. The course was published in Dec 2018, so it takes a bit of wrangling if you're using the latest version of Amplify and the npm modules, but nothing that is unsurmountable with Google to help (that is part of being a developer anyway).

results.content:
Update: Reed has been active in the Q&A, addressing the challenges many of us faced. There are some non-trivial fixes to the code and updates to Amplify that will need to be incorporated into the main course.

Previous review
I tried to make it through the course. I paused and followed Reed through his back-fourth edits. I appreciated that he was talking React in a way that expected you to know it... however, having no interim codebase resets ended up with a non-trivial drift. 

So, I downloaded the "final" project and attempted to work backwards. No dice. I tried to comment out the errors, but can't get a second user to see the first users products. 

Only 6 months has passed since the course went live and the landscape has shifted - Amplify has gone through two non-trivial upgrades in that time. It appears Reed hasn't kept the course fresh, so anyone attempting this course will be at a disadvantage.
results.content_html:
Update: Reed has been active in the Q&A, addressing the challenges many of us faced. There are some non-trivial fixes to the code and updates to Amplify that will need to be incorporated into the main course.

Previous review
I tried to make it through the course. I paused and followed Reed through his back-fourth edits. I appreciated that he was talking React in a way that expected you to know it... however, having no interim codebase resets ended up with a non-trivial drift.

So, I downloaded the "final" project and attempted to work backwards. No dice. I tried to comment out the errors, but can't get a second user to see the first users products.

Only 6 months has passed since the course went live and the landscape has shifted - Amplify has gone through two non-trivial upgrades in that time. It appears Reed hasn't kept the course fresh, so anyone attempting this course will be at a disadvantage.

results.content: Reed has some of the best material on Udemy hands down, honestly... cutting edge courses with really good pacing not to fast not to slow, doesn't spend to much time on fluff. I have bought almost every course he has put out and got a clear understanding of the subject matters quickly. If you are interested in React and Vue and learning libraries, cms, apis, and services integration surrounding frontend frameworks then look no further. Every course he covers a new component library or new backend stack. Worth every penny.

If you are interested in React and Vue and learning libraries, cms, apis, and services integration surrounding frontend frameworks then look no further. results.content: Before buying this course I went through the newest written tutorial about Amplify that I could find, and afterwards felt like I barely learned anything. Reed's course on the other hand is nicely structured, not too long (which sometimes makes me lose interest at some point instead of getting me excited) and he explains things well. I like his calm way of presenting the material. All in all a great intro to Amplify but also to AWS in general. Plus, you get to learn a bit about about GraphQL (basic queries, mutations, subscriptions etc.) and even React hooks (if you want).
results.content_html: Before buying this course I went through the newest written tutorial about Amplify that I could find, and afterwards felt like I barely learned anything. Reed's course on the other hand is nicely structured, not too long (which sometimes makes me lose interest at some point instead of getting me excited) and he explains things well. I like his calm way of presenting the material. All in all a great intro to Amplify but also to AWS in general. Plus, you get to learn a bit about about GraphQL (basic queries, mutations, subscriptions etc.) and even React hooks (if you want).

results.content:
The lessons currently use a severely outdated version of Amplify and AWS CLI toolchains which no longer deploy to AWS. 

If you put in a lot of work to follow along using the newer toolchains, it's possible to use this course. However, the whole point of paying for a udemy course is to have a curated learning environment instead of endless googling... which is what you're currently forced to do to follow this course.

The instructor also goes VERY fast through any coding and provides little or no explanation about what is being done. It would be very helpful to explain why things are done to have context and vocabulary to enable a working understanding.
results.content_html:

results.content:
Pretty perfect course for the level I'm at - i.e. - No need to skip forward because of too much time on basic 'should-already-know-this' content.

As such, if you are a react beginner, this may not be ideal for you, though you could get all the takeaways of Amplify even without knowing react, if that is what you are after.

results.content:
This is a really well-designed course. It does a great job of showing you how beautiful AWS Amplify is. As someone who is more interested in front-end web development than back-end, this service is just awesome.

I came into it having already completed a course about React, and I was already strong with JavaScript in general. I would have been lost otherwise.

There were a couple of ways this course could have been better. The instructor's code is placed after the relevant lessons whereas it should probably be placed up-front. Some courses have the source code for each lesson posted in the lesson itself. This course would have benefited from that, because the final code is actually refactored from the individual lesson videos in many places, so you can't do an exact comparison. Some of the files are really long, and the JSX is complex enough to make your eyes twirl, so you kinda really need that source code in with the video.
results.content_html:
This is a really well-designed course. It does a great job of showing you how beautiful AWS Amplify is. As someone who is more interested in front-end web development than back-end, this service is just awesome.

I came into it having already completed a course about React, and I was already strong with JavaScript in general. I would have been lost otherwise.

There were a couple of ways this course could have been better. The instructor's code is placed after the relevant lessons whereas it should probably be placed up-front. Some courses have the source code for each lesson posted in the lesson itself. This course would have benefited from that, because the final code is actually refactored from the individual lesson videos in many places, so you can't do an exact comparison. Some of the files are really long, and the JSX is complex enough to make your eyes twirl, so you kinda really need that source code in with the video.

results.content: The components that the author uses are outdated and occasionally give an error if you use them. If you go to the FAQ, you can see that other people have been asking questions related to this for more than a year, but the author does not answer the questions, other users usually help.
results.content_html: The components that the author uses are outdated and occasionally give an error if you use them. If you go to the FAQ, you can see that other people have been asking questions related to this for more than a year, but the author does not answer the questions, other users usually help.

results.content:
I couldn't recommend this course more.
This combination of technologies is probably one of the fastest ways to prototype and develop fully fledged, scalable web applications, and you'll be building two along the course.
The instructor seems very knowledgeable about the topic despite being cutting edge technologies.

I'd like to emphasize that the course is not only focused on React and Amplify, but covers GraphQL quite in depth and also provides practical and fast ways of using and integrating extremely useful resources like:
- AWS AppSync (GraphQL) with DynamoDB, including subscription to changes in data in real time.
- AWS S3 both for storage and web hosting for deploying your application.
- AWS Cognito for authentication, authorization and registration.
- AWS Elasticsearch for fast searching.
- AWS Lambda functions.
- Stripe for processing payments.
- AWS SES for sending transactional emails.
results.content_html:
I couldn't recommend this course more.
This combination of technologies is probably one of the fastest ways to prototype and develop fully fledged, scalable web applications, and you'll be building two along the course.
The instructor seems very knowledgeable about the topic despite being cutting edge technologies.

I'd like to emphasize that the course is not only focused on React and Amplify, but covers GraphQL quite in depth and also provides practical and fast ways of using and integrating extremely useful resources like:
- AWS AppSync (GraphQL) with DynamoDB, including subscription to changes in data in real time.
- AWS S3 both for storage and web hosting for deploying your application.
- AWS Cognito for authentication, authorization and registration.
- AWS Elasticsearch for fast searching.
- AWS Lambda functions.
- Stripe for processing payments.
- AWS SES for sending transactional emails.

results.content: Great course, could be slowed down a bit, I have it on 0.75 x and I struggle. It's also good to explain the concepts a bit more - eg. we're building a loop here so it shows all the marketplaces to the user. Rather than just jumping into code. I would also say its a good idea to show what we are going to build before we build it. Other than that it's great and I'm learning lots!
